title: Richard Corbett
text:
Richard Graham Corbett <a href="Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">CBE</a> (born 6 January 1955) is a former British politician who served as the final <a href="European%20Parliamentary%20Labour%20Party%23Leader">Leader</a> of the <a href="European%20Parliamentary%20Labour%20Party">European Parliamentary Labour Party</a> (EPLP), from 2017 to 2020. He was a <a href="Member%20of%20the%20European%20Parliament">Member of the European Parliament</a> (MEP) for <a href="Merseyside%20West%20%28European%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Merseyside West</a> from 1996 to 1999 (under the system that predated the <a href="proportional%20representation">proportional representation</a> regional system) and then for <a href="Yorkshire%20and%20the%20Humber%20%28European%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Yorkshire and the Humber</a> from 1999 to 2009, when he lost his seat, and again from 2014 to 2020. He attended Shadow Cabinet meetings and was a member of the Labour Party's National Executive Committee. 
Between January 2010 and February 2014, Corbett was an advisor to the first full-time and long-term <a href="President%20of%20the%20European%20Council">President of the European Council</a>, <a href="Herman%20Van%20Rompuy">Herman Van Rompuy</a>. In this capacity, and as a frequent writer and commentator on European affairs, he was voted by a panel of retired diplomats, journalists, academics and think-tankers on 14 November 2012 as the fourth most influential Briton on EU policy, ahead of the Prime Minister.
In 2003, Corbett became the first MEP to write a regular personal blog, and in 2015 he became the first British politician to develop and release a phone app.
Education.
Corbett was born in <a href="Southport">Southport</a>, <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, to parents of working-class background from Wales and London. He attended primary school at Farnborough Road School in Southport. When his father was offered a post as a statistician at the <a href="World%20Health%20Organization">World Health Organization</a>, the family moved to <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a>, Switzerland, and Corbett attended the <a href="International%20School%20of%20Geneva">International School of Geneva</a> (attended at the time mostly by children from <a href="UNOG">UN Agencies in Geneva</a>), where he obtained the <a href="International%20Baccalaureate">International Baccalaureate</a>. He was captain of the football team and also played for the junior team of a Swiss second division club.
He won a place at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Oxford">Trinity College, Oxford</a>, the first generation of his family to be able to go to university, and obtained a degree in <a href="Philosophy%2C%20Politics%20and%20Economics">Philosophy, Politics and Economics</a>. He was the Secretary of the <a href="Oxford%20University%20Labour%20Club">Labour Club</a> and chairman of the Oxford Committee for Europe. He co-ordinated the Oxford student 'Yes' campaign in the <a href="1975%20United%20Kingdom%20European%20Communities%20membership%20referendum">1975 referendum</a> on membership of the <a href="European%20Community">European Community</a>. He also skied for Oxford against Cambridge.
Corbett later completed a doctorate in political science at the <a href="University%20of%20Hull">University of Hull</a>.
Political career.
Before the European Parliament.
Richard Corbett's activities in the European Students at Oxford led on to him being elected first to the youth board of the <a href="European%20Movement">European Movement</a> in Britain and then to the international presidency of the youth wing of the European Movement and of the <a href="Union%20of%20European%20Federalists">Union of European Federalists</a>, the <a href="Young%20European%20Federalists">Young European Federalists</a> (JEF), a post he held from 1979 to 1981, drafting their manifesto, which was the first to coin the phrase "<a href="democratic%20deficit">democratic deficit</a>" in relation to the European Parliament's then lack of power over European legislation.
Corbett was secretary-general of the European Co-ordination Bureau of International Non-Governmental Youth Organisations from 1977 to 1981, representing youth organisations in the <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a>'s <a href="European%20Youth%20Foundation">European Youth Foundation</a> and <a href="European%20Youth%20Centres">European Youth Centre</a>. He also helped to set up the Youth Forum of the European Communities, the predecessor of the <a href="European%20Youth%20Forum">European Youth Forum</a>, and represented <a href="Western%20Europe">Western Europe</a>an youth organisations in negotiations with <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>an organisations pursuant to the Helsinki Treaty (as well as at the <a href="World%20Festival%20of%20Youth%20and%20Students">World Festival of Youth and Students</a> in <a href="Havana">Havana</a> in 1978, along with <a href="Charles%20Clarke">Charles Clarke</a> and <a href="Peter%20Mandelson">Peter Mandelson</a>). He worked with <a href="Altiero%20Spinelli">Altiero Spinelli</a> MEP on the latter's proposal for a draft treaty establishing a European Union, adopted by the European Parliament in 1984.
Before being elected to the European Parliament, Corbett worked in the <a href="voluntary%20sector">voluntary sector</a> and as a civil servant, later becoming a policy advisor to and then Deputy Secretary General of the <a href="Progressive%20Alliance%20of%20Socialists%20and%20Democrats">Socialist Group</a> in the European Parliament. He worked on drafting the parts of the treaties of <a href="Maastricht%20Treaty">Maastricht</a> and <a href="Amsterdam%20Treaty">Amsterdam</a> that increased the powers of the Parliament, notably helping to draft the "<a href="codecision%20procedure">codecision procedure</a>" which now applies for adopting <a href="Law%20of%20the%20European%20Union">European legislation</a> through successive readings of the Parliament and the <a href="European%20Council">Council</a>.
In 1992, Corbett was made Ambassador of Goodwill of the US State of <a href="Arkansas">Arkansas</a>, by its then Governor <a href="Bill%20Clinton">Bill Clinton</a>.
First Period as a Member of the European Parliament.
Corbett was a member of the Parliament's <a href="Committee%20on%20Constitutional%20Affairs">Constitutional Affairs committee</a> and from 1999 to 2009 was the spokesman for the <a href="Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29">Labour Party</a>, as well as the whole of the wider <a href="Group%20of%20the%20Party%20of%20European%20Socialists">Group of the Party of European Socialists</a>, on European constitutional affairs. In 2006, he was elected Deputy Leader of the <a href="European%20Parliamentary%20Labour%20Party">European Parliamentary Labour Party</a>, which he remained until the end of his first period as an MEP, declining (to some surprise) to challenge for the leadership when <a href="Gary%20Titley">Gary Titley</a> stood down in 2008.
In 2003, his proposals to re-write the European Parliament's <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20071013075828/http%3A//www.europarl.europa.eu/parliament/expert/staticDisplay.do%3Flanguage%3DEN%26amp%3Bid%3D56">Rules of Procedure</a> were largely accepted. In 2004–2005, he was the co-rapporteur (with <a href="I%C3%B1igo%20M%C3%A9ndez%20de%20Vigo">Iñigo Méndez de Vigo</a>) for Parliament on the <a href="Treaty%20establishing%20a%20constitution%20for%20Europe">Treaty establishing a constitution for Europe</a>. This report formed the basis of Parliament's official position on the treaty, which he was then invited to present to several national parliaments.
In 2005, he was appointed as Parliament's negotiator (along with <a href="Joseph%20Daul">Joseph Daul</a> MEP) to broker a new system of parliamentary scrutiny over Commission implementing measures (under the previously much-criticised "<a href="comitology">comitology</a>" procedure), which led to an agreement among the Council of ministers, the <a href="European%20Commission">Commission</a> and the Parliament in 2006 giving Parliament the right to <a href="veto">veto</a> quasi-legislative implementing measures. This represented a major increase in Parliament's powers over the Commission.
In 2007–08, he was again co-rapporteur with <a href="I%C3%B1igo%20M%C3%A9ndez%20de%20Vigo">Iñigo Méndez de Vigo</a> for Parliament on the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>, (which replaced the constitutional treaty after two member states had declined to ratify it) and was again rapporteur for a new overhaul of Parliament's procedures in 2009, 2016 and 2018.
Throughout his career, Corbett has been a strong advocate of EU reform and has a particular interest in improving democratic accountability by continuing to increase the European Parliament's power within the EU institutional system. Professor Juliet Lodge of Leeds University has named Corbett as one of five "movers and shakers" in the European Parliament who "have brought the European Parliament from being a mere talking shop to a legislature with genuine power".
Corbett's voting record and other parliamentary activities can be found on the VoteWatch website.
Five years out of the European Parliament.
Corbett lost his seat in the <a href="2009%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">2009 European Parliament elections</a>, which saw a big fall in the Labour share of the vote in the wake of the <a href="Westminster%20expenses%20scandal">Westminster expenses scandal</a>. The <a href="British%20National%20Party">BNP</a> took the seat. The <a href="BBC%20News">BBC</a> website carried the following comment from their European editor, <a href="Mark%20Mardell">Mark Mardell</a>:
Mark Mardell had previously referred to Richard Corbett as:
After his defeat, Corbett spent two months in Ireland from August to October 2009 helping (behind the scenes) the "Yes" campaign in the second <a href="Twenty-eighth%20Amendment%20of%20the%20Constitution%20of%20Ireland">Irish referendum</a> on the <a href="Lisbon%20Treaty">Lisbon Treaty</a>, in which 67% of the 59% turnout voted in favour.
In December 2009, he was invited to join the private office ("<a href="President%20of%20the%20European%20Council%23President%27s%20office">cabinet</a>") of the first full-time President of the <a href="European%20Council">European Council</a>, <a href="Herman%20Van%20Rompuy">Herman Van Rompuy</a>, as his advisor on constitutional issues, but also handling his relations with the European Parliament and national parliaments, with the <a href="European%20Committee%20of%20the%20Regions">European Committee of the Regions</a> and the <a href="European%20Economic%20and%20Social%20Committee">European Economic and Social Committee</a> as well as helping on relations with some governments, including the UK.
Return to the European Parliament.
Corbett left the Van Rompuy "cabinet" in March 2014, in order to stand for election in the <a href="2014%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">2014 European Parliament elections</a> as the Labour party's second candidate in Yorkshire & Humber. In Labour's internal ballot of party members to choose their candidates, Corbett came first (with the highest proportion of first preference votes of all new candidates in the country) securing him second spot on the list of Labour candidates, behind the sitting MEP <a href="Linda%20McAvan">Linda McAvan</a>. Labour won two seats in the election in Yorkshire, and so Corbett was returned to the Parliament.
In Parliament, Corbett returned to the Constitutional Committee and served also on the Fisheries Committee (as a full member) and the Economic Committee (as a substitute). He was elected again as Deputy Leader of the Labour MEPs in September 2014. He was again rapporteur for a new overhaul of Parliament's procedures in 2016 and 2018–19. On 25 October 2017 he was elected Leader of the Labour MEPs (EPLP) following the retirement of <a href="Glenis%20Willmott">Glenis Willmott</a>, defeating <a href="Si%C3%B4n%20Simon">Siôn Simon</a> and <a href="Clare%20Moody%20%28politician%29">Clare Moody</a> in the vote.
As Leader of the EPLP, Corbett was a member of the Labour Party NEC and attended Shadow Cabinet. In these roles, he was heavily engaged in the internal party discussions that eventually led to Labour calling for a new referendum on Brexit. He spoke at some of the large marches in London and elsewhere calling for a peoples' vote on the final Brexit deal.
In advance of the <a href="2016%20United%20Kingdom%20European%20Union%20membership%20referendum">United Kingdom European Union membership referendum</a>, Corbett launched an app called "Doorstep EU" for <a href="IPhone">IPhone</a> and <a href="Android%20%28operating%20system%29">Android</a> in order to debunk myths about the EU, deliver authoritative briefings on key issues and detailed statistics of the EU's impact on the United Kingdom.
He supported <a href="Yvette%20Cooper">Yvette Cooper</a> in the <a href="2015%20Labour%20Party%20leadership%20election%20%28UK%29">2015 Labour Party leadership election</a>, <a href="Owen%20Smith">Owen Smith</a> in the <a href="2016%20Labour%20Party%20%28UK%29%20leadership%20election">2016 election</a>, and <a href="Keir%20Starmer">Keir Starmer</a> in the <a href="2020%20Labour%20Party%20leadership%20election%20%28UK%29">2020 election</a>.
After Brexit.
In 2021, the European Parliament asked Corbett to represent it in the Common Secretariat running the <a href="Conference%20on%20the%20Future%20of%20Europe">Conference on the Future of Europe</a>, while simultaneously being "Deputy chef de cabinet" to the Secretary General of the European Parliament.
Other activities.
Richard Corbett versus the UK Independence Party.
Richard Corbett was an early critic of the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20Independence%20Party">United Kingdom Independence Party</a> (UKIP).
In June 2004, he drew attention, in "<a href="The%20Independent">The Independent</a>" newspaper, to UKIP links with the far-right <a href="British%20National%20Party">British National Party</a> in that year's local elections: "In Yorkshire, where both the <a href="British%20National%20Party">BNP</a> and UKIP put up candidates, they appear to have come to an arrangement not to stand against one another".
Richard Corbett's pamphlet "25 Things You Didn't Know When You Voted For UKIP".
Following Ashley Mote's imprisonment in September 2007 for fraud, Corbett called on the government to change the law which allowed the former UKIP MEP to be paid in full during his spell in jail. The Minister responsible for payment of MEPs (and MPs), <a href="Harriet%20Harman">Harriet Harman</a>, promised to look into the matter.
Corbett continued to campaign vigorously against the UK Independence Party in the run-up to the 2014 European elections. After they secured the biggest share of the vote in these elections, he subsequently wrote "I think it is a mistake to focus exclusively on UKIP's racism. That unsavoury side of UKIP has been adequately exposed by others [...] We need to expose them on their policies".
Sports policy.
In 2006, Corbett served on the Independent European Sport Review, set up by several national governments and <a href="UEFA">UEFA</a> and chaired by the former <a href="Portugal">Portuguese</a> Deputy Prime Minister Jose Luis Arnaut. The review was in fact about the governance of football, and Corbett chaired the sub-group on political aspects. The review paved the way for a number of changes introduced by UEFA, among them the 'Financial Fair Play' rules. Corbett has maintained an interest in the governance of football ever since, taking up a number of issues with UEFA.
Grimethorpe Colliery Band.
Corbett is the Honorary President of the <a href="Grimethorpe%20Colliery%20Band">Grimethorpe Colliery Band</a>, a brass band based in Grimethorpe, South Yorkshire. The band achieved worldwide fame after appearing in the film "<a href="Brassed%20Off">Brassed Off</a>", as well as becoming (along with Black Dyke Mills Band), the first brass band to perform at the Proms.
Labour Party positions.
Corbett has held a number of offices in the <a href="UK%20Labour%20Party">UK Labour Party</a>. As well as being Deputy Leader and, from October 2017 until Brexit, Leader of the <a href="European%20Parliamentary%20Labour%20Party">European Parliamentary Labour Party</a> (EPLP), he served on the Regional Board for <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a> and the party's National Policy Forum, a position to which he was re-elected by fellow Labour MEPs in May 2014. He was national chair of the <a href="Labour%20Movement%20for%20Europe">Labour Movement for Europe</a> from 2009 to 2011, and subsequently served as one of its Labour MEP representatives.
As Leader of the EPLP, Corbett was a member of the <a href="National%20Executive%20Committee%20of%20the%20Labour%20Party">National Executive Committee</a> (NEC) of the Labour Party and attended <a href="shadow%20cabinet">shadow cabinet</a> meetings.
Other organisations.
Corbett is Vice Chair of the UK <a href="European%20Movement">European Movement</a>, having served as Chair following the resignation of <a href="Laura%20Sandys">Laura Sandys</a> in the wake of the 2016 referendum result. He did not want to continue as Chair, citing time constraints, and handed over to <a href="Stephen%20Dorrell">Stephen Dorrell</a> in December 2016.
Academic.
Corbett was a Visiting Professor at the <a href="College%20of%20Europe">College of Europe</a> in Bruges and on the board of the Salzburg Centre for European Union Studies (SCEUS) of the <a href="University%20of%20Salzburg">University of Salzburg</a>.
He has written numerous academic articles and books (see '<a href="Richard%20Corbett%23Publications">Publications</a>' below)
Publications and communications activities.
Corbett is the co-author of an eponymous academic textbook on the European Parliament (now the standard reference book on it across Europe) and several other academic publications (see below).
Corbett was an early user of new media. In 2003, he was the first MEP from any country to launch a <a href="blog">blog</a>, which he resumed in 2014 as part of his election campaign. In 2004 his website was cited as one of the most comprehensive of any British politician's by "New Statesman" magazine, which nominated him for a New Media award. In 2015, he became the first MEP to launch a mobile app, Doorstep EU, aimed at activists, journalists and other politicians. In the same year, he also took part in an <a href="r/IAmA">AMA</a> on <a href="Reddit">Reddit</a>.
Corbett starred in the docudrama film "Do it like a European?", which won a prize at the international Winton Film Contest.
Languages.
Corbett speaks <a href="English%20language">English</a>, <a href="French%20language">French</a>, <a href="German%20language">German</a> and <a href="Dutch%20language">Dutch</a>.
Personal life.
Corbett lives in <a href="Shipley%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Shipley</a> near <a href="Bradford">Bradford</a>; he formerly lived in the nearby village of <a href="Saltaire">Saltaire</a>, for whose <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">World Heritage Status</a> he helped to campaign. As an MEP, he had his constituency office in <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a>, where he shared premises with <a href="Hilary%20Benn">Hilary Benn</a> MP.
Corbett is married to Lorraine Kirkwood and has three children.
